skill.name: env-manager
skill.description: Environment variable management, validation, and documentation.
skill.summary: Environment variable management, validation, and documentation.
skill.author: CuriousLearner

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only instructional markdown content. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, no command execution. This skill provides guidance on environment variable management practices.

content.value_statement: Managing environment variables across different environments can lead to errors, security issues, and configuration headaches. This skill helps you validate, document, and secure environment configurations for any project.
actual_capabilities: Analyze code to identify environment variables in use
Validate environment variable formats and required values
Document environment configurations with descriptions and defaults
Provide security recommendations for secret handling
limitations: Does not modify files on your filesystem
Does not execute shell commands or scripts
Does not access or read existing .env files
Does not connect to external services or APIs

use_cases.title: Set up new projects
use_cases.description: Generate environment configuration templates for new projects with proper validation and documentation

use_cases.title: Audit configurations
use_cases.description: Review environment variable usage across codebases and identify missing or misconfigured variables

use_cases.title: Enforce best practices
use_cases.description: Verify projects follow secret management guidelines and do not hardcode sensitive values

prompt_templates.title: Generate template
prompt_templates.scenario: Create env file for new project
prompt_templates.prompt: @env-manager Generate a .env.example template for a Node.js application with PostgreSQL, Redis, and JWT authentication

prompt_templates.title: Validate variables
prompt_templates.prompt: @env-manager What environment variables are required for a production Node.js application and how should they be validated

prompt_templates.title: Document secrets
prompt_templates.prompt: @env-manager Create documentation template for environment variables including descriptions, examples, and security notes

prompt_templates.title: Security audit
prompt_templates.prompt: @env-manager What security best practices should I follow for environment variable management in production

output_examples.input: @env-manager Generate .env.example template for a Node.js API
output: Security notes: Never commit .env files, use secrets manager in production
Validation: Use libraries like envalid to check types on startup

best_practices: Use a validation library to check environment variables on application startup
Keep .env.example committed to version control with placeholder values
Use different configuration files for development, staging, and production environments
anti_patterns: Hardcoding secrets directly in source code
Committing .env files with real credentials to version control
Skipping validation and letting missing variables cause runtime errors

faq.question: Does this skill read my .env files?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based skill that provides guidance. It does not access or read any files on your system.

faq.question: What languages does it support?
faq.answer: The guidance applies to any language. Examples include Node.js, Python, and other languages using environment variables.

faq.question: Can it validate my existing configuration?
faq.answer: The skill provides validation patterns and examples. Actual validation requires integration with your application code.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill runs entirely as a prompt response and does not transmit data, access files, or execute code.

faq.question: What validation libraries are recommended?
faq.answer: For Node.js: envalid or dotenv. For Python: pydantic-settings or python-dotenv with manual validation.

faq.question: How is this different from other config management tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides conceptual guidance and templates. Tools like Docker Secrets, AWS Secrets Manager, or Vault handle actual secret storage and injection.
